skill.name: git-commit
skill.description: Use this skill when user asks to "commit changes", "create a commit", "stage and commit", or wants help with git commit workflow.
skill.summary: Generate conventional git commit messages based on staged changes with automatic type detection.
skill.author: 21pounder

security_audit.summary: The skill safely executes git commands as its core functionality. Static analyzer flagged 29 patterns but all are false positives: documentation examples using markdown backticks, security guidelines warning against committing .env files, and metadata in the JSON template itself. The skill follows secure practices and has legitimate use of external commands through the Bash tool.

low_findings.title: Legitimate git command execution
low_findings.description: The skill executes git commands (status, diff, commit) using the Bash tool which is explicitly listed in allowed-tools. This is the intended functionality for a git workflow skill. Commands use safe arguments without user input injection.

content.value_statement: Developers waste time crafting commit messages and struggle to maintain consistency across team repositories. This skill analyzes git changes and automatically generates properly formatted conventional commit messages.
actual_capabilities: Executes git status and git diff commands to analyze repository state
Generates conventional commit messages following the type(scope): description format
Automatically detects commit type (feat, fix, docs, refactor, test, chore) based on file changes
Stages files using git add before creating commits
Creates commits and returns the commit hash for verification
Reviews recent commit history to match existing message style
limitations: Requires an initialized git repository to function
Cannot infer the business logic reason behind code changes
Generated messages may be too generic for commits affecting multiple unrelated modules
Does not validate commit message against team-specific linting rules

use_cases.title: Speed up daily development workflow
use_cases.description: Developers can commit code faster by delegating message generation to the skill. The skill examines git diff output and produces properly formatted messages that follow conventional commit standards.
use_cases.target_user: Software engineers working on feature development

use_cases.title: Maintain consistent repository history
use_cases.description: Teams maintain uniform commit message formatting across all contributors. The skill ensures every commit follows the same type(scope): description pattern which enables automated changelog tools.

use_cases.title: Learn commit message best practices
use_cases.description: Junior developers see examples of well-structured commit messages. The skill demonstrates imperative mood, appropriate type selection, and clear descriptions that explain the purpose of changes.
use_cases.target_user: New developers learning version control workflows

prompt_templates.title: Basic commit request
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to create a commit with automatically generated message

prompt_templates.title: Specify commit type
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a fix type commit for my changes
prompt_templates.scenario: User knows the commit type and wants to enforce a specific type

prompt_templates.title: Include scope in commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Commit these changes with type feat and scope auth
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to specify both type and scope for the commit

prompt_templates.title: Override with custom message
prompt_templates.prompt: Commit my changes with message: Update user authentication flow to support OAuth2
prompt_templates.scenario: User has a specific commit message they want to use

output_examples.output: The skill runs git status and git diff to examine your staged changes. It detects that you added a new authentication module in src/auth.ts and corresponding tests. The skill generates the commit message feat(auth): add user authentication module and creates the commit. The output shows the commit hash abc1234 and confirms the commit was successful.

output_examples.input: User says: Create a fix commit for the parser bug
output_examples.output: The skill examines your staged changes in utils/parser.js and identifies this is a bug fix. It generates the commit message fix(parser): resolve null reference in string parsing following the conventional commits format. After creating the commit, it reports the commit hash def5678 and verifies the working directory is clean.

output_examples.input: User says: Commit with message: Refactor database connection logic
output_examples.output: The skill uses your custom commit message exactly as provided. It stages the changes in db/connection.js and creates the commit with your specified message. The skill reports the commit hash and does not attempt to modify or reformat your message.

best_practices: Review staged changes with git status before invoking the skill to ensure only intended files will be committed
Provide additional context in your request when changes are complex or span multiple concerns
Verify the generated commit message accurately describes your changes before accepting the commit
anti_patterns: Committing without reviewing the generated message to ensure it matches your actual changes
Staging sensitive files like .env or credential files before using the skill
Overriding the skill with custom messages that violate conventional commit format

faq.question: What format does the skill use for commit messages?
faq.answer: The skill generates messages following conventional commits format. This format uses the pattern type(scope): description where type is feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, test, or chore.

faq.question: Can I override the generated commit message?
faq.answer: Yes. Include a custom message in your request using the message parameter. The skill will use your provided message instead of generating one automatically.

faq.question: How does the skill determine the commit type?
faq.answer: The skill analyzes git diff output to detect what changed. New features trigger feat type, bug fixes trigger fix type, and documentation changes trigger docs type. You can also specify the type manually.

faq.question: Will the skill stage files before committing?
faq.answer: Yes. If you have unstaged changes, the skill can stage them before creating the commit. You can specify which files to stage in your request.

faq.question: Does this work with GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill works with any git repository regardless of where it is hosted. It only uses standard git commands that work universally.

faq.question: What happens if my commit affects multiple modules?
faq.answer: The skill identifies the primary affected area as the scope. For commits that touch many unrelated areas, consider providing a custom message or splitting into multiple commits.
